Reviews.Title: “Disappointment is Directly Correlated to Expectation”
Reviews.Author: DrACruz
Reviews.Content: Lower your expectation then everything in life will turn out as icing on the cake. The basic expectation from the ‘ladies and gentlemen’ of Ritz Carlton is their smile, service, and personality. Instead, at Ritz Carlton Hong Kong, my wife and I saw a lot of ‘long faces’ and were embarrassed for not knowing how to go to our room after we checked in. The view from our room is magnificent but the hospitality industry is a people- and service-oriented business—software is far more essential than hardware!

Reviews.Title: “Loved the service at the Ritz”
Reviews.Author: Londoner016
Reviews.Content: This is a top class hotel situated in the West Kowloon area. Although quite isolated for first timers and a bit of a schlep to get to the MTR through a shopping mall, we were glad we stayed here for 2 nights. Top of the attractions is Ozone, the world's highest bar - the cocktails were good and the views were incredible. I did wonder though when we were there, whether it was worth shelling out for a room when it is easy to access this bar for non-hotel guests. In fact there is a steady stream of visitors to this hotel and no separate lift for guests - it does seem a bit overcrowded at times. The superb levels of service make up for this. And while there may be some gloating at how visitors can get the views without paying thousands of dollars for the room - they miss out on the views at breakfast from the superb lounge area. There is also something said for being able to relax in one's own room and enjoy the views in privacy. We have travelled all around the world, but we commented that this was one of the first times we just sat and stared out of our hotel window. Unfortunately due to the thickness of the glass and the fact that the hotel is so high up - visibility can be poor and is nowhere near as impressive as the Intercontinental. The decor of the rooms though is exquisite - it was our first time at a Ritz Carlton hotel and it will be very hard to get accustomed to anything else. The bathroom was so luxurious - the size of the shower head the biggest we have ever seen - all part of the Ritz Carlton experience. THere is also a TV in the bathroom if you like that kind of thing. A very high tech hotel, you feel as if you are on the set of a James Bond movie at times. Incidentally, the lounge area is an excellent spot for some pre or post dinner cocktails. Service is at all times fast and efficient - the staff have been trained to the highest standards - as expected for the price you will be paying for this hotel. My only criticism is that at times, the Ritz seemed a bit too corporate and clinical. The minimalist design is great, but what is missing is warmth - this is an area that could be improved.

Reviews.Title: “Best place to stay in HK !!!”
Reviews.Author: BorisTGChicago
Reviews.Content: Brand new hotel, super clean, superb service, great location, best recommendation for HK !!!!

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel I have stayed in”
Reviews.Author: Voyager26
Reviews.Content: The prospect of staying in the 4th highest building in the world was intriguing. But the service and attention to detail blew me away. Just nothing is too much to ask, they do it. Arranging a pick up at airport for a group, check in logistics, arranging a city tour. Leave an item at reception by mistake? You find it in your room. The location next to the most pretty (& big) Elements Mall a bonus.

Reviews.Title: “Nice spot to visit and great view”
Reviews.Author: Freddyboi
Reviews.Content: This place is gorgeous. 103 floors up to the bar with a crazy view of Hong Kong. The bar on the 102 floor was very elegant with chandeliers and a live person singing. This is a def place to visit when traveling to Hong Kong.

Reviews.Title: “Chandeliers”
Reviews.Author: Pawe Ł
Reviews.Content: Hi . IN march 2011 I assembled chandeliers in the baal room on 3rd flooor and on 113 th floor. During my work I could admire views in and out of the building. Realy its impresive and luxury place, but propably only for rich people

Reviews.Title: “Must Stay”
Reviews.Author: SirGoldenCircle
Reviews.Content: Located on the 108 floor of the building. It takes some time from ground floor to the main reception. Very posh, very nice view. Ozone on the top floor is a must to visit.

Reviews.Title: “Best Hotel in Hong Kong”
Reviews.Author: blacklaw
Reviews.Content: Just stayed there over the weekend. Some people complained that the wall is paper-thin, yet I didn't find it to be a problem. My room was very quiet and the bed, very comfortable. The room is also spacious and luxurious. wifi internet (free) is also very fast and reliable. Anyone who stays there must use the pool located on the 118th (which is the highest in the world), the out-door jacuzzi offers an amazing view of the city, which is better than the crowded and noisy O-zone on the other side of the 118th floor. The breakfast is also impressive. There were wide array of choices of food and they are all delicious. Be sure to get there earlier, so you can get the window seats, which gives you a bird's eye view of the city. In my opinion, the new Ritz now tops Four Seasons and the Peninsula, which I also stayed earlier this year. However, its Italian Restaurant, Tosca, is expensive, but not as good as many other fine choices in town, such as Amber or 8 1/2 Otto.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic!”
Reviews.Author: NilsP
Reviews.Content: The Ritz-Carlton HK at the ICC offers exclusivity in the world's highest hotel. The Club rooms from floor 108(!) gives you access to the Club Lounge 24/7. It offers a host of canape style foods with a decent selection of drinks and hot beverages. The staff are very attentive and polite. The Spa is worth a visit and if you're looking for a trendy, fashionable bar lounge with a good selection of food and drinks and a live DJ and a bar lounge that offer spectacular views then look no further then the Ozone - also based at the hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing!!”
Reviews.Author: L0veB0nes
Reviews.Content: Very fancy. We were there for 1 night only. And what a great night!! The view from the room was really stunning!! Nice big bath tub. There is a mall next to the hotel where you can get to it from inside the hotel. Staff are very helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel (if You Want to Be Close to ICC)”
Reviews.Author: RNG1008
Reviews.Content: Stayed for 8 nights at the Ritz Carlton HK for a business trip and it was fantastic. I'm personally not a fan of Kowloon side but most of my meetings were at the ICC. Beautiful hotel, fantastic room (my room on was the 108th floor), love the decor and design. Rooftop bar was fantastic (apparently highest bar in the world). Directly connected to the MTR and ICC where there's plenty of shopping and restaurants. For someone visiting HK for the first time for pleasure, you should stay in the HK side and not Kowloon. For business travelers, especially those meeting / working at ICC, this one is a no-brainer. Great hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular, inefficient building”
Reviews.Author: Baba1956
Reviews.Content: Ritz Carlton is hotel which opened in May in HK. Location is fabulous, with spectacular views of the sky line of HK. It still has some teasing problems. Some of them will be solved, some are impossible. I assume the architect of the beautiful and spectacular very tall building didn't design a hotel b4. Why only 4 elevators to go up with limited capacity so waiting time is long. On top the elevators are built to confuse. And work not very well with the roomkey. Finding your way in this hotel to the restaurants is also complicated. Everything is located at different floors and directions. Business centre is impossible to find, no directions wherever. Hidden somewhere, in a corner,plus again in different part of the hotel. Rooftop Gym is spectacular and great machines. Pool same!! Highest indoor pool in the world? Restaurants are fine, food not extraordinary. Service is ok, but few staff are not very fluent in English. Rooms are fine, bed super, comfortable including Ipod, Nespresso machine etc.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing to say the least”
Reviews.Author: 325irollin
Reviews.Content: Loved everything about it. Service was the best. Room on floor 117 was amazing. View is stunning. Club Lounge is a must! Very nice staff there and you can get food/drinks any time of day. Pool and Ozone bar on floor 118 were both wonderful. Phoebe in the lounge was very nice and shared a convo about tattooes since I was in HK for a consultation. Check-in and out were easy and smooth. No problems at all. One of the best hotels I've been to. Expensive of course but you get what you pay for, that's for sure! Will be back!

Reviews.Title: “Wow”
Reviews.Author: John R
Reviews.Content: Being stuck in Hong Kong is never a good thing. but we choose to find a good hotel due to this fact and we picked the Ritz Carlton. Yes its right downtown. A good and bad selling point. But its the location where the whole water line can be seen that makes this a great spot. Ground level was nice but at the checkin at the 103rd floor made it even better. And then finally we got a room on the 117th floor as the hotel upgraded us. The pool is on the top fllor at 118thThe view was fantasic with on the building their lights flickering and flashing over looking the harbour and central. The room was nice with 2 big beds and the washroom was all slate and marble. Yes my credit card was melting but at that moment I did not care. So what can I say but spoil yourself once in a while.

Reviews.Title: “Its the perfect place to live”
Reviews.Author: Sharon O
Reviews.Content: Yes, the 6 words used by my 4 year old daughter when she first walked into the room that we were staying in. The fantastic view, coupled by the superb amenities and service made the stay so much more enjoyable, esp after a long day of shopping in HK. We had a hard time trying to get our daughters (2 and 4 yo) out of the room, even to go for breakfast at the club floor. When we are out they will be pestering us to go "home", ie the hotel. SO we ended up going back early to enjoy the room and the view. Greatly recommended for everyone and esp families with kids.

Reviews.Title: “initial hiccups?!...or just poor mgt?”
Reviews.Author: weechuan
Reviews.Content: just arrived from jw marriott where i stayed for 5 nights w superb service to attend a wedding held here. Check in was painfully slow. platinum marriott card holder, was upgraded to a hong kong island view room. but no lounge access. its been 2hours 10 mins since i arrived in my room.my luggages are still missing. not impressed so far! i hope they have not sacrificed or camouflaged core service quality and standards with a fancy superficial frontage.

Reviews.Title: “Wow, amazing place”
Reviews.Author: Colette_p84
Reviews.Content: I couldnt believe this hotel. i didnt stay, but had dinner and used the spa....currently the tallest in the world at 116 stories high, the swimming pool was another two stories but. swimming 118 floors up is both exhillerating and terrifying. the pool is amazing, with a computerised ceiling. the jacuzzi is 'ouside' in a bit where the building seems to open up. i had never seen anything like it! the spa was lovely, i had 3 hours of treatments, a salt body scrub, followed by a massage, followed by a facial. i was in another world after!! after the treatments you get to relax snuggled on day beds, wrapped in huge covers, wt curtains to give you pricacy, a tone of magazines, herbal tea. you then have a delicious lunch served by the pool. ammmmmazing treat, if you are in hong kong, try and do this for a decadent treat!

Reviews.Title: “On Top Of the World”
Reviews.Author: Manojvora_11
Reviews.Content: Hotel is the highest hotel in the world from 103 floors to 118 floors. Swimming pool on 116 floor. Night club , Ozone on 118 floor, partially open to sky.Excellent Rooms,Bathroom and service. Great location. Kowloon station is below the hotel. Checkin from station to Airport directly.Only hitch is no network at such heights especially sea facing rooms except China Mobile..

Reviews.Title: “Sheer Luxury with a Wow factor!”
Reviews.Author: Travelling_Craze
Reviews.Content: How to go? You can take the Airport Express to Kowloon station. Hotel is just right above this station. Room: I stayed at Premier Island Suite and was at level 109. It is basically a corner room that gives a panoramic view of Victoria harbour and the views are amazing! You got a bay windows where you can sit there to enjoy the day and night spectacular views. The room size is fantastic! There is a working desk, a small living room, a bedroom and a huge bathroom. The amenities in the room are quite good. Mini fridge, ipod loaded with musics on docking speakers (one in bedroom + one in working desk), two large Lcds TV (one in living room + one in bedroom), magazines etc.. The bed is from Sealy and it is really heavenly!! The curtains are controlled electronically so you can draw them up with a topuch of your finger tips. The pillows are very good too. Complementary bottle waters are there with complementary newspaper and wifi in the room. There is also complementary fruits. Bathroom: The bathroom is simply gorgeous. It is of a very good size. It has two entrances. The first entrance is just next to the main door which leads you to the toilet. The next entrance is connected to the bedroom which is separated by sliding door. It has a nice bathtub with a head rest for you. So that you can soak comfortably and watched TV at the same time as there is a nice little in built TV facing the tub. However, I feel that the viewing height and angle of the TV is not good. I try soaking in the tub and I find at this angle, the TV show appears dark from my angle. Showering area is next to the bathtub with very generous rain forest shower. The bathing amenities are from Asprey. The towels are of good size and feel. There are two basins for you and partners. Services: When I arrive at the entrance lobby, someone helps me with my baggage and a lady escorts me to the hotel lobby at 103. Then, I was ushered to level 116 for personalized check in which is their club level. The staffs speaks good English, very attentive and friendly. The check in is pretty fast. Check out is equally quick at the same place. There is turn down services and they leaves some little chocolate which is housed in Ritz box. Amenities and breakfast Level 118 houses the swimming pool and the jacuzzi. There are 3 jacuzzi. Two indoor (hot + cold) and one outdoor (hot). I was there at night and there are not many people which is good. The swimming pool bathroom is spacious and the design is nice too. The toilet cubicles are all circular in shape. I have accessed to the 24 hours club and so far it has the most food presentation ever. Total 6 meals presentation daily! You basically can eat every second! Though no lunch and dinner, the snacks and drinks spread are quite good and you can easily filled up your stomach and forgo lunch and dinner. Breakfast selection is ok as expected due to lesser people on club floor. Hotel: The location of the hotel is quite good. A shopping mall - Elements is linked to this hotel. It is a pretty upscale mall where you can get all your favourite branded stuffs here with no queues. A cinema and ice skating rink can also be found here. There are also many eateries and cafes. If you decide to venture out, Kowloon MTR station is just underneath. Going to Airport is also extremely easy as the Airport express is just below and you can do city check in too at there!!! Very convenient. Verdict: Staffs are very friendly, helpful and attentive. A huge room with harhour views that are amazing. A shopping mall and MTR station connected. I really cannot think of a reason not to say YES to this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Simply amazing”
Reviews.Author: Ariel16
Reviews.Content: I was seriously impressed by the level of service of the staff in this fabulous hotel. Nothing is left unattended and you don't have to worry about anything at all, starting from checking in to luggage delivery to everything in the middle. The hotel is stunning and the rooms spacious and welcoming. The view is superb. Would love to go back!

Reviews.Title: “Excelent service”
Reviews.Author: stropmaitland
Reviews.Content: Just a quick note on the hotel. Stay was 3 days from the 26-10-2011 Service was fantastic with the staff always very attentive to your needs weather asked or not, but not over the top. Views are fantastic. Special thanks to Tony the concierge and Joe the assistant manager for the Ritz at the airport who remarkably organised a flight for me when the Quantas drama unfolded. I had already checked out of the hotel 2 hours previosly. With what they organised I actually left 2 hours before the scheduld departure time of the Quantas flight. I think this is the difference in staying in a top quality hotel. Will see you again.

Reviews.Title: “Must be nice - on a clear day”
Reviews.Author: Yellowlab3944
Reviews.Content: Location is in the middle of major construction zone. Not easy to get to unless by MTR. It's all on what must be landfill. From Ozone bar on 118th floor you can hear roar of jets coming from HKIA - a bit unsettling. Weather in HK can be hazy. Not much to see on hazy days. Must be amazing on clear days. This is a hot location with tourists and locals. Service staff overwhelmed easily by crush of crowds.

Reviews.Title: “What a treat!”
Reviews.Author: dingmax
Reviews.Content: This is our second visit to the 118-storey high Ritz-Carlton Hong Kong (as a local) and we enjoy every minute of it. You can command a good view of the Victoria Habour and the food/beverage presentation in the Club Lounge is excellent - can you impagine, a free flow of 8 kinds of wine 24 hours non-stop. We will be back whenever we have an excuse...

Reviews.Title: “A breathtaking vue”
Reviews.Author: Voilacestmoi
Reviews.Content: Of course the Ritz-Carlton is excellent, what else. But this time you will just never forget your stay. The view from every room is amazing. And having breakfast with that view is just breathtaking. Don't miss the pool on the 116th floor!

Reviews.Title: “Incredible view... at a price”
Reviews.Author: jamesjen25
Reviews.Content: Located over 100 floors up on the Western part of Kowloon, I would recommend shelling out the extra cash needed to get a harbourview room – rather than one that looks over inland – then buying a bottle of wine and enjoying the view for the rest of your stay; this should more than cover the marginal cost incurred. Though I live in Hong Kong, with the re-opening of the Ritz Carlton at the top of the glitzy International Commerce Center of Kowloon, I was extremely curious as to the quality of the view (and of the hotel). There was, and to some extent remains, a tremendous amount of hype to the hotel and its restaurants, and it remains difficult to secure a reservation at its two restaurants. The rooms were very nice – modern, well-equipped and luxurious. The bed was great, and the bathrooms were spacious and comfortable. However, aside from Nespresso coffee machine at the minibar (with free capsules), I cannot say that anything in the room particular captivated my senses… aside from the magnificent view outside my window. Fate was smiling as we were blessed with sunny and clear days (as well as nights), which meant that we could enjoy the lovely view of Hong Kong island unimpeded by any unwanted elements. I also visited the popular bar/club Ozone, located at one of top floors. The only big negative I can offer is that since there was no elevator that goes directly to guestrooms – all guests for the restaurants, rooms, and Ozone had to pass through the lobby located on the 103 floor – it may be a little daunting, or downright embarrassing, for a hotel guest to saunter through the lobby in casual attire. I tried, and my shorts and slippers felt extremely out of place surrounded by dolled up individuals and groups looking to have a grand night out. +++: View: I’ve been to the peak in Hong Kong more than once to show visiting friends around, but I have never seen Hong Kong Island like I saw it in this hotel room. The view from the room was a spectacle, and we were fortunate enough to be able to enjoy it without the presence of smog. One of the special moments included drinking a chilled bottle of champagne whilst admiring the night show and scenery. Absolutely magical (and romantic!). Bonus tip: to enjoy the same-ish scenery at a more earthly level, I would definitely recommend the lounge in Intercontinental Hotel (Salisbury Road) at Tsim Sha Tsui Rooms: Comfortable and luxurious rooms, while nothing out of this world, are more than worthy of the Ritz name. While I myself am more taken by the modern utility and convenience of rooms, this room also impressed my travel partner, whose tastes are a little more traditional and cozy. The Nespresso machine and a powerful ceiling shower were my favorite touches. ---: Location: Don’t get me wrong, the Ritz is located atop Elements, a bustling mall with tons of restaurants and shopping choices, a cinema, and is even connected to a railway line that goes directly to the airport. But Hong Kong is much more than one mall, and in that sense the location may seem a little distant from the usual touristy haunts of Causeway Bay, Wan Chai, and Central (Lan Kwai Fong / Soho). And even if you’re thinking of staying in Kowloon, hotels in Tsim Sha Tsui and Mongkok would definitely provide more cost-effective and convenient lodging. Identity crisis: The Ritz has established itself as a high-end food and drink destination (although I am not sure whether this status is deserved or not as I did not dine-in), and is a victim of its own success. Due to a high volume of fashionable people coming to the Ritz for the club and restaurants, guests might feel a little marginalized. Firstly, while the staff was always courteous, the high influx of non-hotel guests made the service feel forced and sterile. Secondly, being constantly surrounded by well-heeled individual made it difficult to relax in the lobby, or even feel comfortable wearing ultra-casual attire. Lack of free Wifi: One would think paying close to US$800 for a room would include free internet…

Reviews.Title: “Amazing”
Reviews.Author: Daniela L
Reviews.Content: Room, service, food, view, and location were nothing short of amazing. Very impressed with service. Any time I called for anything, they were very accommodating and at your door before you know it. Room service food was delivered on time, hot, and delicious. Would definitely return when coming to HK.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular Views (But Only on Clear Days)”
Reviews.Author: honeydewchase
Reviews.Content: We stayed for one night at the newly opened Ritz Carlton in Hong Kong. The hotel is on the Kowloon side (not the most convenient for most tourists) at the top of a skyscraper. Our room was on the 111th floor so we could only see clouds from our window. However, on a clear day, the views of the Hong Kong skyline (if you have a room facing the Hong Kong side), must be amazing. The service is very good----I left a bathing suit behind and we were immediately contacted. The pool, which is on the top floor is open to the air, and was the highlight of our stay. What we did not like was the decor of the rooms (multiple clashing beiges and golds) and the fact that you have to take (if you are coming in from the mall (yes, the hotel is part of a mall complex), which is what you will do if you come in and out from the subway), at least 3 escalators and 2 elevators. It can take a good 10 minutes to get up to your room.

Reviews.Title: “A million dollar view; top notch gadgetry; cookie cutter, clinical service”
Reviews.Author: sejok
Reviews.Content: Where do I start? Well let's look at the location. Occupying the 103-118th floors of Hong Kong's ICC building can have many benefits. It sits atop the Kowloon train station (MTR and airport express) so transportation is good... That is, unless you have luggage and a 4yr old in tow. I suspect your typical Ritz Carlton guest doesn't generally take public transport, so the hike from train to hotel can be quite arduous. (Think 6-8 flights of escalators + 2-3 elevator trips). Also, in terms of location, the shopaholic within cannot have any complains. With the elements mall within the complex, all mid-market to top notch name brands are accounted for. H&M to Ferragamo, you're covered. And then, there's the view. Did I mention 118 floors? We were assigned rooms on the 106th and if there's one thing that blows you away, (other than the bill at the end of the stay) it's the gorgeous views of all of Hong Kong on a clear day.  On a typical day however, I fear the view may be limited by smog. At this juncture, assuming vertigo is not a concern, another great thing the hotel has going for it is the amenities. Anything you want ala the Ritz Carlton is available here... Nespresso machine check, Tv in bath check (double check if you're a 4 yr old), free wi-fi, remote curtains and proximity sensor key cards, check, check, check. Swimming pool on the 118th floor, heated till perfection with a view like no other, check mate. So, sounds great so far, and it was. The only reason I'm not giving this hotel a 5 star rating are twofold. 1) They already have an official 5 star rating so they probably don't need one from me and 2) I thought the service left a little to be desired. Check-in. Mechanical and not particularly welcoming. Here's your key, turn left, tap your key card, press 106, go to room, sleep. Don't call us, we'll call you. Check-out, efficient. Here's the bill. Where I didn't feel particularly welcomed was at the arrival lobby on the 9th floor. (that's where you get on these jet-propelled elevators which send you to #103). Here, they're all smiles when you leave, but of course they need to check your credentials when you arrive.  After all, not everyone should be entitled to ride in a jet-propelled elevator. My problem was that the same lady who greeted us so warmly coming down also seemed to want to stop us from going back up 2hrs later. Do I really need to explain that I stay there? It seems that the reason may be due to a throng of locals for high tea every weekend. They're meant to queue for hours on end at the arrival lobby and not use our rocket ships willy nilly. Also, I was half expecting that the Ritz would do something special for a 4yr old. Granted that this wasn't the Disneyland hotel, but these things matter to a parent! Tv in the bath notwithstanding, I got the impression that the Ritz didn't know what to do with a 4yr old... Is she gonna bite us? Will she know what to do with the chocolate we leave on her pillow? Oh lord she's got a stuffed toy. Erm what's that? The thing that took the star away: On our first night (15 Oct 2011), a fire alarm went off at 2.30 in the morning. (Did I mention I had a 4 year old in tow?) which is all well and good because fire alarms saves lives. I wasn't looking forward to a 106 floor climb down to safety, but i guess i would have if necessary... What REALLY annoyed me, was a string of announcements that followed saying that it was a false alarm. Repeatedly. In every language known to man. Repeatedly. (Did I mention I had a 4 year old in tow?) of course, nobody took my calls, nobody heard my pleading for them to shut up and nobody could help me with my irate 4 year old. Of course in a hotel with the clinical efficiency of the Ritz, there was no further mention of the rude awakening. Any mention was met with a salute-like apology. Stoic, uniformed and reserved. Next time in Hong Kong, I think I'll pick a hotel closer to the ground.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacularly Expensive, Spectacular Luxury and Ruined by checkout.”
Reviews.Author: DrKazza
Reviews.Content: I took my wife for her birthday for a one night stay and in general we had a fantastic time. Unfortunately all the good work done by the staff was ruined by some jumped up little smug minimanager on front desk with an attitude, and also by Ritz Carlton's penny grabbing service charge. The rooms are fantastic, really well decked out, fantastic views and bathrooms are exceptional. I asked for a bouquet of flowers and a bottle of champagne for her birthday, they sorted this out and also left a birthday cake for her... very nice touch. Impressed - thank you Tosca...very nice... we had a great meal here. The food was very high end food and fantastically cooked. Although the high quality of the food meant that the menu was quite limited. Great for a one off trip, but too limited to come back time and again. (Pigeon starter was great and the veal papardelle likewise - prawn linguine was a bit too fishy. Desserts were spectacular) The Staff in Tosca were brilliant, they really looked after us and helped us have a great meal. Although, the courses came pretty quickly... I think they wanted to close the kitchen, we were seated at 9:30 and they had taken our main course away by 10:15. Fast food much? Breakfast the next morning had a good selection and was again of a high standard. Now the bad: I coughed up a fortune for a one night stay with breakfast, including dinner you're looking down the barrell of 1400 usd.. now you think that this may be enough for ritz carlton... OH NO. Front desk: "Sir did you have anything from the minibar?" Me: "Yes two waters" lo and behold when it appears on the bill, 40HKD per bottle of water and 4HKD service charge. Me: "SERVICE CHARGE? for what?" FD: "It's the rules""It's the rules""It's the rules""It's the rules""It's the rules" Me: "I don't want to pay it... service charge is optional" FD: "It's the rules, in hong kong you have to pay service charge" Me: "Thank you for spoiling my stay" it's NOT the rules that service charge is mandatory in Hong Kong, it's just an idiot with an attitude on the front desk. here's a tip for the ritz carlton... Service charge is for SERVICE PROVIDED... the clue is in the name. If I get a bottle of water out of the fridge myself, then YOU OWE ME for the service I provided myself. Bottom line, almost everyone worked really hard to make it a great experience and it was fantastic, until the last person I met managed to spoilt it. well done. well done indeed. My Recommendation: Book dinner at Tosca, go for a drink at Ozone, see the views, get the good service, and then go and stay at the Mandarin or the 4 seasons across the harbour.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular Hotel in every sense”
Reviews.Author: Skidog33
Reviews.Content: Stayed at The Ritz Carlton for 4 nights in a suite. Very impressive luxury hotel.Lives up to the hype.Very nice to arrive at the Ritz in Mercedes Benz S Class Limo. Then be welcomed by four staff and escorted through two huge reception areas to your beautiful suite on the 113th floor for in room registration and familiarization of the wonderful facilities. Seeing the panoramic view for the first time was mind blowing.I loved the spacious Club Lounge with five separate servings, with open bar 24 hours. It is easily accessible on the 116th floor. Herve, Club Lounge manager was extremely efficient and courteous.One of the few negatives was number of groups from the Main Land, which tended to detract from the exclusiveness of the hotel.However once on your secure lift floor, you are in your own private domain. Dined at the Cantonese restaurant and ordered the set menu.Food was good but we felt rushed as the restaurant was fully booked. Should have asked for more time between servings and I think a la carte would have been better value. Generally I appreciated the excellent service in the hotel and all my requests were met speedily. The late check out of 4pm was ideal. The high life is not hard to take.

Reviews.Title: “The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong's Suite Dreams Package is a Nightmare Come True”
Reviews.Author: Goblins G
Reviews.Content: I booked the Suite Dreams Package offered by The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong, as I wanted to treat my boyfriend to a surprise birthday weekend getaway. The Suite Dreams Package is described as “Dreams come true at The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong. Indulge in a romantic getaway with your beloved and create a memory that will last a lifetime.” HUGE MISTAKE. I cannot emphasise enough how misleading this description is. Do NOT fall for this package. The description should in fact read, “Nightmares come true at The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong. Unromantic getaway with your beloved. Scar yourself with memories that will haunt you for a lifetime.” The Suite Dreams Package is described as including an “arrival limousine transfer (any destination in Hong Kong)” and an “80-minute aromatherapy massage for two” among other things. However, the service I received for both of these items was severely inadequate. Firstly, regarding the arrival limousine transfer, I was surprised to receive an email from the concierge a day before the actual transfer, informing me that the local transfer would be HK $450. Confused, I wrote back to enquire if the transfer was not already included in the price of the Suite Dreams Package. The concierge replied that it was indeed part of the package and apologised for the confusion. This was a teeny tiny blunder compared to what was to come. The limousine was to pick up me and my boyfriend at 1 PM the next day. To cut a long story short, the driver went to the wrong building, 5 minutes away from our place. When we realised that the driver had made a mistake, I informed him that our building was 300 metres down the street. He asked me to “wait 5 minutes”, which seemed a reasonable amount of time to cover that distance in a Mercedes-Benz. By the time the limousine arrived, it was 1:45 PM. We arrived at the hotel a minute or two past 2 PM. Upon arrival, the hotel staff came up with all kinds of excuses to explain the blunder and avoid blame. These excuses ranged from the management of my building not allowing the driver to wait there to the driver being held up by protesters en route to picking us up. None of their excuses were plausible. There has never been a problem with vehicles waiting before and our building even has a designated parking area for taxis and other pick-ups. Furthermore, the rather low frequency at which protest marches at lunch time on National Day occur in our residential neighbourhood makes the excuse of the driver being slowed down by protesters unlikely. Most importantly, given the fact that the driver himself had told me he was at a building just 300 metres down the street from ours, it should not have taken him more than 5 minutes maximum to drive to the correct pick-up location. By the time we were shown to our hotel suite, it was 2:10 PM and I had to cancel our 1:45 PM lunch reservation at Inakaya, a restaurant I had really looked forward to dining at and had reserved more than a month in advance. The restaurant had kindly been holding our table, but their kitchen was closing at 2:30 PM. The hotel compensated by arranging a table for us at The Lounge & Bar, one of its own outlets, where we ate a club sandwich and a pad thai on the house. This in no way made up for our disappointment at missing the chance to dine at Inakaya. What made matters even worse was the 80-minute aromatherapy massage “for two” included in the Suite Dreams Package. After arriving at the spa, my boyfriend was led to the men’s changing room and I to the ladies’ to get changed for the massage. Imagine my shock when the therapist escorted me to a massage room for one person. I asked the therapist where my boyfriend was, and was told that we would be having our massages in separate rooms. This surprised me as the Suite Dreams Package is described as a “romantic getaway with your beloved” and separate massages in separate rooms is the exact opposite of romantic. I asked the therapist if there had been an error. The therapist informed me that to get a couple’s room, I had to upgrade at a price of HK $900 or so. Since money was not an issue, I asked her to upgrade us to a couple’s room right away. The therapist told me that the two couple’s rooms were full and had to be booked in advance. My boyfriend and I ended up having the 80-minute aromatherapy massage “for two” in separate rooms. Right after the massage, I postponed the romantic dinner “for two” at Tosca by 30 minutes as I urgently needed to express my frustration with the massage as well as my growing fear that the dinner would be just as disastrous as the massage experience. By phone, I told the duty manager that any reasonable person would assume that the aromatherapy massage “for two” included in the Suite Dreams Package would be in a couple’s room since the package is described as a “romantic getaway with your beloved”. He apologised and told me that he would check what the Suite Dreams Package should include. I also informed him that after the separate and unromantic massages that my boyfriend and I had, I was extremely distressed that we would be seated at separate tables for the romantic dinner “for two” at Tosca. He assured me that he would personally see to it that the dinner arrangements would be up to standard. Fortunately, it turned out that my boyfriend and I were indeed seated at the same table for dinner. However, the damage had already been done by the unromantic and separate massages, which was now the second part of our package that had not been properly executed, causing distress and anxiety for me on what else would go wrong, and I could hardly enjoy dinner that night. As we sat down for dinner, we asked for the wine list. We never got it and were served rosé champagne on the house instead, in addition to an extra dessert near the end of our meal. I appreciate the gesture, but knowing that my boyfriend does not like rosé wine and I generally don’t drink alcohol at all, I would much rather have chosen a wine to my boyfriend’s liking from the wine list. As for the extra dessert, it was delicious but unnecessary as we already had dessert included as part of our meal. After careful consideration more than a month in advance, I chose The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong to celebrate my boyfriend’s birthday weekend over other five-star hotels such as The Peninsula and The Mandarin Oriental. Being a newly opened and much talked-about hotel with a world-class reputation, I was confident that this was where we would experience, according to the hotel slogan, an “elevated luxury lifestyle”. However, this was not the case. My biggest complaint is, of course, the 80-minute aromatherapy massage “for two” in separate rooms. I can honestly say that I did not enjoy a single second of the 80-minute massage as I was simply too much in shock wondering how the hotel could market the Suite Dreams Package as romantic. Any guest will assume that a spa treatment that is part of a “romantic package” is to be enjoyed by a couple, together in the same room without the need to book an additional upgrade to a couple’s room in advance – and for HK $900. However, since this is not the case, the hotel is seriously misrepresenting the Suite Dreams Package and misleading its guests. As for the gestures made by the hotel staff to apologise for the blunders, all I can say is too little too late. The lunch on the house to make up for the lunch my boyfriend and I missed at Inakaya and the additional items that were given to us at Tosca after the bungled separate and unromantic massages do not make up for the fact that I was severely distressed during the 45-minute wait for the limousine, disappointed at missing our lunch at Inakaya and, worst of all, spent an agonising 80 minutes during the massage, separated from my boyfriend, wondering how things could have gone so wrong and terrified of what the next blunder was going to be. I started planning my boyfriend’s surprise weekend getaway more than a month in advance, but it turned out to be nothing like I had envisioned it to be. The only member of staff I felt was naturally hospitable and welcoming was Mr Nils Berghäuser at The Lounge & Bar. On the actual day of my boyfriend’s birthday, he kindly escorted us to a table with the best view in the entire restaurant where we had complimentary champagne and a mini birthday cake with our breakfast. I would like to take this opportunity to sincerely thank him for making us feel welcome during our last meal before checking out. However, one hospitable member of staff is not enough to ever make me want to return to The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong. I had one chance to make my boyfriend’s birthday weekend special and to “create a memory that will last a lifetime”, as the Suite Dreams Package is advertised. I will definitely remember my weekend at The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong, but not in the way I had hoped. The front office manager gave me his name card as I was checking out, asking me to call him to arrange a romantic dinner the following weekend to make up for all the blunders. His gesture, no matter how well intended, simply cannot make up for the fact that my boyfriend’s romantic birthday getaway was an absolute catastrophe. The hotel staff had their chance to make this past weekend spectacular for me and my boyfriend and failed us miserably. Not only did they ruin the entire weekend, but they also ruined the actual day of my boyfriend’s birthday as I remained in a miserable mood instead of the celebratory mood I had hoped to be in. I do not see why I should give the staff the chance to ease their conscience. Guests who choose to stay at The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong, choose to do so because they expect top-notch service. I no longer have such expectations from The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong. I warn any couple looking for a romantic getaway NOT to choose The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong’s Suite Dreams Package. Doing so will cause you grief as I learnt the hard way. If you are looking for impeccable service and a blunder-free getaway, do NOT consider The Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong, but go to The Peninsula or The Mandarin Oriental where you are guaranteed a five-star-hotel-worthy experience.

Reviews.Title: “Highest hotel in the world”
Reviews.Author: Henry T
Reviews.Content: This is a new building with very good view of Hong Kong whether your room is facing the city or the harbour. Service is excellent in all areas starting from recption lobby, restaurant and buisness centre. However, one may pay attention to the poor reception of mobile and blackberry which caused my equipment searching for network all the day.

Reviews.Title: “the best hotel i've ever been in my life!”
Reviews.Author: gugliada
Reviews.Content: i've been in hong kong end of august 2011 after a long trip around oceania and asia. I needed to be cuddled and i was! i travelled with my partner, we had an upgrade in a suite. the best room, the best service we've ever had in our life! the spa is really great and the swimming pool is... WOW! the only bad thing was regarding the top floor bar, which is wonderful, but full of tourist... i mean HOTEL TOURISTS... people that come over just to see the hotel... and it was quite annoying that we hardly find a table because of that. for the rest, i can't say anything bad. it's a wonderful place, great service.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular”
Reviews.Author: RomainLouise
Reviews.Content: We stayed two nights at the Ritz Carlton HK on our way back from Europe to Oz and absolutely loved it. It beats flying business :) The room was simply gob smacking and luxurious. The service was nothing short of phenomenal. We went a month after they opened so the staff were still trying to figure a few things out, however they were very gracious. The pool and gym is a must do, to swim at 492 m overlooking HK Island is a must do. We also had a couple spa treatment, this was by far the nicest spa suite we have seen. This is a true luxury hotel with some of the world best view. We will definitely be back.

Reviews.Title: “Ritzy, Glitzy and Ditzy”
Reviews.Author: vinz20
Reviews.Content: Ritzy Definitely pricey to pay for the awesome day view even though I was given an upgrade to a Suite (Junior Suite I think). Well furnished, impeccably clean. Was disappointed by the night view from my room and the club lounge. Hong Kong Island and Kowloon were not brightly and adequately lit. Not a spectacular suite compared to other 5 star hotels but bed was extremely comfortable for a good night sleep. Love the bath-tub with foam bath, salts and TV in bathroom (wide selection of channels) Glitzy Awesome swimming pool. Water was a bit chilly for my liking especially in the morning. Nice hot & tubs jacuzzis. Club Lounge – excellent for pitstops and my favourite destination at the Ritz. Club is opened 24 hours and you can have light breakfast, lunch, tea and dinner. There isn’t a proper supper but you can help yourself to cookies, chocs and beverages. They have a selection of 4 reds and 4 white wines, international beers, champagne, soft drinks and juices. Altho, the strict dress code of smart casual wasn’t adhered to by some guests, at least they were decently attired in Bermudas, t-shirts and footwear. Complimentary use of computer, internet and phone for local calls. There is a decent library with a TV. Top marks to the Club ladies; Phoebe & Natalie who were extremely attentive, helpful and friendly. There was one occasion after 11pm when I couldn’t access the Club Lounge with my electronic card key as it was not working. I was subsequently let in by Phoebe who had already finished her shift for the night at 11pm. The next day when she saw me, she approached me, offered to change my card key and apologized for the inconvenience of the night before. I had thought she wouldn’t have remembered. Ditzy Suite design was ditzy and doesn’t look spacious. As you step into your suite, there is a side door which opens into the water closet (WC) area and a wash basin. This is linked to your main bathroom area as well as to your bedroom. The suite proper leads you to the minibar, nespresso area before the work desk area which is obstrusively situated in the middle of your living room. The bedroom is located near the end of the living room and with sliding door partitions from the living room and bathroom. Disappointed that a cupboard was provided and not a walk in wardrobe. As pointed out by one contributor, if the cupboard door is open, it blocks your way to the bathroom area. Also, if you open the door to the WC area, it blocks access to one of the wash basins in the bathroom. Instead of a wash basin in the WC area, I think a bidet would have been better. Although, I had indicated to Reservations that I had a child accompanying me, no child amenities were provided. It was only on the 2nd day that they provided a child bathrobe (too small) and a bath towel. Altho, i was shown to my room by a Reservations Lady, i thought she could have taken the trouble to give me a quick orientation of the room and its amenities as some top hotels do. As I was meeting friends in HongKong, I didn’t get a chance to try the F&B outlets at the Ritz. Had no problems with the key card (the trick is to hold the key card long enough and in the correct zone of the scanner) and waiting time for lift was OK. Altho, i booked a club room, i didnt check in at the club lounge. In any case, there wasnt any queue and check in was fast and hassle free. Luggage wass promptly delivered Practical Information Conveniently located above the Kowloon MTR station with direct access from the Airport. Walking time to the Ritz is between 10-12 minutes. Just follow the directional signs once you are in Elements Mall (mall with premium outlets like Louis Vuitton). There are plenty of shops and restaurants, even Starbucks, a cinema, ice skating rink in the Mall. You can access certain other parts of Kowloon and HongKong island taking the free airport express buses located near the MTR station. Overall, a very good hotel, well located but no particularly unbelievable service experience to warrant a 5 star rating.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful staff. Wonderful view.”
Reviews.Author: thephantomtraveller
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 2 nights. The experience was fantastic. Personal service throughout our stay. Checking in and out was efficient. Our room was at the 117th floor. A magnificent view welcomed us as we entered. The furnishing has a warm yet modern feel. The nespresso machine was a nice touch specially for caffeine addicts like us. The club floor offers 4 'meals' per day. We found the afternoon tea and chocolate buffet most enjoyable. What better way to end your day with a bird's eye view of hongkong surrounded with champaign and chocolates?

Reviews.Title: “Need to iron out the wrinkles...”
Reviews.Author: atlas1059
Reviews.Content: In the past, I have always been one to jump at trying a new hotel. But after staying at another the newly opened Ritz Carlton (this time in Hong Kong in April 2011), I have decided that I should stop being a glutton for punishment and be a little bit more patient. The Arrival. Firstly, finding the entrance to the hotels was an adventure in itself. I am very familiar with HK and it's landmarks, but finding the entrance was a trip. The main entrance from the mall / MTR was closed and still under construction. The only way in was from another level through countless escalators. There were no signs ... only a piece of paper taped to the wall. After finally reaching the lobby, you were stopped by young ladies holding an iPad. I understand the feeling the hotel is trying to create with technology, but it was a little unnecessary as each name had to be checked off on the "list" before allowed entry. As we stayed on the Club Level, we were escorted to the Club Level check in where it was pretty cut and dry. It took about 5 minutes and we were taken to our room. I read some reviews where check in was a mess, but I think I lucked out because I stayed there during the first few weeks of its opening and the hotel was only about 30% full. The Room. When you step into the room, the name Ritz Carlton does not come to mind. It seems more like a modern boutique hotel or a Mandarin Oriental. I've stayed at countless Ritz Carltons around the world and you come to expect a certain decor and style. The HK Ritz is quite different with straight lines, minimalist furniture and a very transparent bathroom. It wasn't my cup of tea, but hey, I just needed a place to sleep...I wasn't going to live there permanently. But what bugged me the most was the fact that the toilet didn't really flush. You would actually have to flush at least 4-5 times before the toilet paper disappeared. The Service. The service was definitely lacking and I attributed it to the fact that it was a new hotel and everyone was still scrambling around...for what you ask? I don't know. You were either greeted in Mandarin (which is wild, because you're in HK where people speak Cantonese and not Mandarin) or greeted by a person who was so unhappy to work there that you wanted to tell them that they should just quit their job already. There are a few other reviews where guests encountered the same thing. It's just very odd. What was even funnier was an incident where I was in the elevator when it opened on one of the levels and the GM had quickly peeked in and saw some people and then quickly retreated trying not to be noticed. He actually tried to hide and not come in...there were only 2 people in the elevator at that time. I can only guess he didn't want to hear all the negative comments guest had. Oh, and how did I know her was the GM? I saw the same guy in the lobby minutes later with his name tag on. I guess he took the next elevator. The Dining. Extremely lack luster and disappointing. Even the food at the Club Level was dry and aged. We had breakfast there and the choice was small and very minimal. We dined at the Cafe Lounge downstairs and the food was extremely overpriced for the quality and quantity you received. I think that the kitchen was still tweaking everything because the people next to us had complained about their food so much that they were given complimentary meals. The Departure. We checked out at the Club Level and everything seem to be painless until they overcharged for our stay by HK$1000 (US$150). Of course they denied that we were overcharged. In return, we showed them our reservation confirmation. The gentleman insisted that our reservation was incorrect, but out of courtesy, he would check. We had timed our check out to give ourselves about 20 minutes just in case something happened. We had given him a copy of the Ritz reservation for him to research the issue, but it still took him about 25 minutes to tell us he still didn't know. He would need to wait for the Reservation Desk and would email us any information he got. And of course, we were late, so we had to leave. At the airport, we received an email from the gentleman stating that they had indeed made a mistake and would reverse the charges on the invoice. Ironically, on that same revised invoice, there was a new charge of HK$25 (US$3.00) from the dining room that was billed to our room AFTER our check-out and departure. You're all probably thinking I'm petty to gripe about US$3, but it wasn't mine! I wasn't even on the premises at that time. To make a long story short (too late), it took me 2 months to sort the invoice out. Again, they had no clue as to how the new charges showed up, but it was another error. So...in conclusion, I would not recommend staying at new hotels. Even companies like the Ritz need time to work out the kinks in their system.

Reviews.Title: “The views make it. Otherwise Ritz Carlton top quality.”
Reviews.Author: Turicus
Reviews.Content: I stayed here 4 nights. The room was a corner room and large for Hong Kong. Big bed, desk, 2 sofas, telescope with tripod in the corner. The design is very modern and stylish but not over the top. Felt really comfortable in the room and other hotel areas. Checkin and checkout were fast and efficient. The equipment was top level, as you would expect from such a hotel. Nespresso machine, large TV, small TV above the bathtub, rain shower, nice amenities etc. The breakfast is excellent. Huge selection of foods, Asian and European, amazing view, good service. I did not eat at any other restaurants. The bar on the 118th floor is cool, well-designed and has the same great view, but service was terribly slow. 20 minutes at the bar for 4 drinks is just unacceptable in a 5* venue. The pool is very nice, also with a view and there are several hot and cold jacuzzis, one outside on the 118th floor. The gym is good for cardio equipment but does not have a lot of resistance machines. Good set of light to heavy dumbbells, though. Service was impeccable, except the bar I mentioned. No further comment. Obviously the views are amazing, that's what you're going for. The pictures are right and you will be ooh-ing and aah-ing when you walk into the room. Pro-tip: get a card with the hotel's name and address in Chinese when you go out, because taxi drivers often speak very little English.

Reviews.Title: “Stunning interiors and design! Among Asia's top 5 hotels!”
Reviews.Author: cosmopolitan77
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the new Ritz Carlton in Aug'11 for just one night (sadly not more) and were 100% satisfied with our experience. The hotel is located on the 103rd - 118th floor and the views over Hong Kong are fantastic!! We usually stay at the W Hotel but this time we wanted to try something new, so we chose the RC because it also has direct access to the Elements mall and the airport train at Kowloon station. We stayed in a Club Room with island / harbor view, and although the room was a bit small it was enough for one night. Next time we might choose the Junior Suite. The view from the room is stunning and it is well worth paying a bit more to get the Hong Kong island view!! The Club Lounge is located on the 116th floor with stunning views. They serve breakfast, snacks and drinks all day, afternoon tea, evening canapes, late night dessert and all night snacks. The lounge is open 24h/day. There could be more staff at the lounge though, as now they were almost nonexistent and service quite slow. But the breakfast and evening canapes were both very good. We arrived early in the evening and had dinner at the hotel's Italian restaurant located on the 101st floor (also with stunning Hong Kong skyline views). The food and service was very good! The hotel interior design and public spaces are among the most beautiful, sophisticated and modern we have seen ever. The amount of details and decorations is amazing. Nothing has been left for chance, and every small detail has been thought through and has been put there for a reason. It is really a state-of-the-art design hotel, not at all like the usual Ritz Carlton hotels. The innovative style, impeccable taste and in-depth understanding of art, fashion, trends are impressive. If you are into hotel and interior design, this is definitely a place to visit! We will for sure go back the next time we are in Hong Kong!

Reviews.Title: “Stunning Hotel and Views”
Reviews.Author: Bernadette1107
Reviews.Content: I had been waiting for the Ritz Carlton to open for a couple of years and was very much looking forward to the trip as I had heard so much about it. The hotel is quite stunning and the views are breathtaking. However, there are a few start up problems. One aspect is the lifts, especially trying to get up to the 103rd floor from the arrival lobby. You wait and wait and wait and I sometimes i thought that perhaps there should be a dedicated lift for the hotel guests. The lift cards were a constant problem in not scanning to the requested floor. In fact, it was quite irritating, especially when it occurred three times in the space of one hour! Another problem is soundproofing. You can literally hear everything going on outside of your door. Not good when there are people in the corridor at midnight. It's a problem that the hotel might want to solve. But, in fairness, it has only been open since March 2011 and there are bound to be some teething problems, but for the price you pay, you should be able to have some privacy. The hotel staff were wonderful and I can't thank them enough for the hospitality that they gave me and the hotel is worth the trip overall.

Reviews.Title: “Forget Victoria Peak - I've got a view from the RC”
Reviews.Author: rodjune
Reviews.Content: Several recent TA posts before mine sum up my stay at the RC HK. It was stay here or the W Hotel and I think I chose wisely! I had a corner room on the 113 floor with access to the club. Check in at the club (rather at the standard registration desk) was relaxing with the club manager, Mr. Yen, recognizing my exhaustion from having done some heavy shopping earlier that day, and offering the beverage of my choice. I had also arrived just in time for afternoon tea, and sat in the lounge for sometime to enjoy the incredible views and wide variety of teas, sandwiches, biscuits, and fruit. Breakfast the next morning was delicous while seated at a window-side table with a wonderful view of Hong Kong below. The guest room was modern, clean, and felt more like walking into someone's home due to the spaciousness and a configuration of the corner room, which overlooked Central, Lantau Island, and the New Territories. While the view was spectacular, the bathroom was pure luxury with a deep soak tub and shower stall with a rain showerhead of incredible size and water pressure. I liked the TV monitor hidden behind the bathtub mirror. The sink area had a long light that illuminates right through the lower edge of the sink counter serving as a nice subtle night light/mood lighting. The bath products were by Asprey. The bedroom and the bed was incredible and very comfortable. The drapes system was electric operated. There was a nice small sofa for gazing out the window and a telescope to view distant places. There was a nice desk, art work, Nespresso machine, and minibar. Even the artwork in the room was special. Besides the club I really loved the pool and hot tubs on Floor 118. The pool had projecdtion screens on the far wall and on the ceiling that was interesting to look at and add an added dimension to what is usually boring indoor pools. I met some nice travelers while sitting on the edge of the outdoor hot tub and we shared our impressions of our travel plans throughout Asia. I will return to this property because of the great hotel employees, the pool (must be experienced to appreciate), the club, and the views that are unmatched.

Reviews.Title: “Simply stunning!”
Reviews.Author: MC-7
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Ritz Carlton for the weekend and could not be more impressed with this property. We have stayed in a number of Ritz Carlton hotels around the world and this is certainly a stand out. As with all Ritz Carltons, everything is luxurious and modern and with this hotel, they've not spared any expense. Upon arrival you are met with very friendly bell staff who take your luggage immediately, whilst someone else escorts you up to the reception level. Our booking included the Club Lounge, so check in was done on Level 116, with exceptional service greeting us straight away. We arrived earlier than expected so our room wasn't quite ready so we waited in the lounge, enjoying the drinks, snacks - and the view! Our room was ready very quickly and when we entered we were completely awestruck. The view of the harbour from our room (level 115) was absolutely spectacular. The floor to ceiling windows (with window seats) allow a completely unobstructed view of Hong Kong, which is obviously second to none. The room itself was great, with everything you would expect from a Ritz - huge rain shower and lovely large bathroom, comfy bed with loads of pillows and even an Ipod pre-loaded with about 2500 songs. There's also a nice armchair where you can take in the night skyline and enjoy the nightly lightshow. We had cocktails at Ozone bar, which is just amazing. The atmosphere is very young and trendy, which isn't necessarily what people expect of a Ritz, however if this isn't your kind of bar, there is a more sedate lounge/cocktail bar on level 102 you can enjoy. Cocktails are actually very reasonably priced and served by very attentive staff. If your room doesn't have a harbour view, head to Ozone, which is on the rooftop (level 118). Again, the view is fantastic! We also had dinner at Tosca, the Italian restaurant on level 102, and although there have been mixed reviews about the meals, decor and surrounds, we thought it was wonderful. We had a window seat and enjoyed great wine and wonderful food, again served by wonderful staff. The comments about being watched by customers at the Chocolate Library above Tosca are unfounded - they're not watching you, they're appreciating the view outside!! We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Ritz Hong Kong and will definitely stay again. We really also need to highlight how good the Club Lounge is. Although it costs a little more, it is worth every cent. It's open almost 24 hours a day (closed for only about 30 mins), where you can enjoy food, drinks and privacy from the crowds. The attentive staff make you feel welcome 100% of the time and go out of their way to help you. Herve Yen absolutely deserves a special mention, he is extremely friendly and helped with a number of things - least of all securing our booking at Tosca at short notice, when bookings are taken 2 months in advance! When compared to other Hong Kong hotels, the Ritz Carlton is expensive. However, you simply can't compare this hotel to any other - it's in a class of its' own and you can see exactly what you're spending that extra money on. Definitely worth staying here, at least once!!

Reviews.Title: “Wow! Over the top, literally.”
Reviews.Author: china4me
Reviews.Content: Wow! Over the top, literally. We truly enjoyed our stay at this new Ritz-Carlton property. All properties have their good and bad points. This property was no different. The best thing about this property was the view of Victoria Harbor from our room on the 107th floor. Naturally, the Ritz-Carlton hospitality of its ladies and gentlemen were well represented by everyone we encountered. The room was of good size, well stocked, and very comfortable. On the down side, the elevator situation was a bit of a pain as you needed to take two elevators from ground level to and from your guest room and three from the ground level to the Ozone bar on the 118th floor (two from your guest room to the Ozone bar). The Ozone (loud, dark, and a non-relaxing environment) was not my style of bar, but was obviously appealing to younger guests. However, it lacked the Ritz-Carlton class and dignity that I’ve become to know and love. If you’re in Hong Kong, you need to give a try!

Reviews.Title: “Best of the Best”
Reviews.Author: alstar5
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for High Tea and to experience the overall atmosphere since the change of location. In my opinion, this is the most luxurious hotel available in Hong Kong. You will not be disappointed!

Reviews.Title: “Nice view, nice room, but bad service - not up to HK or Asian standards”
Reviews.Author: ibscotty
Reviews.Content: I travel regularly throughout Asia on business so I'm pretty used to the high quality of service in Asian hotels, particular 5-star hotels like Four-seasons, Mandarin Oriental and Shangri-La. In this case, I arrived late after being delayed by a typhoon. I notified the hotel that my arrival would be delayed and eventually checked in around 8pm. Keep in mind, I did the hotel a favour by telling them I would be late. On checking in, I asked for a late check-out and was told I could leave at 2pm. If I wanted to stay later, I could call the next day to see if any of the guests were delayed so that I could go later. At 1230, I called and asked to delay my check-out and was told that I had to clear the room by 1pm. When I told them that I had originally been given a 2pm checkout, I was told that they were very busy and that they needed the room. They were polite, but firm on the 1pm checkout. That's 30 minutes to shower, pack and check out. This was a first for me, and I thought of the scene from Ocean's 13. I made it out at 1305 and registered my frustrations to an uninterested clerk at the front desk. Just to add fuel to the fire, later in the day, after picking up my bags from the concierge, I asked for a place to change and freshen up. Normally I would be directed to the gym/spa, but in this case, they directed me to a toilet on the way to the mall! The view is great, and the rooms are top quality, but I think there are some growing pains on the service side for this new hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Very good experience”
Reviews.Author: sk9758
Reviews.Content: I literally made a last minute change in my itinerary and stopped in Hong Kong just to experience the tallest hotel. It was indeed an excellent experience. Upon arrival we were whisked to 2 sets of elevators until you reach the Club lounge where our check in was done. We had a Premier Island suite connecting to a deluxe room. To be frank, this was my major disappointment as I really expected a much better product from a brand new RC property for its suite. It has been commented upon very nicely by a previous critic as well and I fully agree. It was nearly the same size as the deluxe room except that it was divided oddly into a small living room and a bedroom separated by a partition. There was no guest toilet or powder room as such. Otherwise I don't have any other quibbles and it was an excellent stay. The lounge offerings were marvelous and of top quality. Staff were par excellence from every aspect. Quality of toiletries and furnishings were also top notch. And yes of course, the views! Aaaaah!! I spent the entire stay just looking out. The pool on the top most floor along with the jacuzzi was to die for! The hotel is indeed overly pricey but if you take the Club floor you get a good deal. The location of the Elements Mall was helpful below us for the dining options and for those who would like, to check in and go to the airport by train as well.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing view but disappointing service for 5 star.”
Reviews.Author: CarmenSandiego1985
Reviews.Content: We got a room facing HK island and the view is simply to die for. The windows are from ceiling to floor and you get a breathtaking view of the city and port with no obstruction since the hotel is so high up. The room itself was very spacious, comfortable and clean (although I would have preferred marble to carpeted floors). However, for the kind of money you are paying, we were quite disappointed with the service. I'm not sure if it's because the hotel is new or what, but most of the staff seemed lost. Check-in took exceptionally long and the woman who took our passports forgot about us for a while until we reminded her we were waiting. The line-up for check-in was pretty long so I think others were facing issues there as well. Also, the business center closes very early and is actually closed on Sundays... They did open it up for us when we asked, but it took a while to get the manager there to approve it. Not what I expected from a hotel that the Ritz touts as one of its best. The menu for in-room dining after 11PM was also extremely limited to ~10 dishes like salads and sandwiches mostly. I thought they'd have a 24/7 kitchen or at least a nice variety of food for people who want to order room service. The pool area was nice, although it was indoor. The hotel only occupies the top few floors of the tall building, so from the ground floor of the building you need to take an elevator up to the lobby, then walk across the lobby to another set of elevators to get to your room. It was a big tedious after a while, but that they can't change. Overall, the only selling point of this place is the view considering the prices they charge for a room ($600 USD/night for a double when we stayed). For those with the money, it's a nice novelty experience. For those who don't to dish the money to stay there, you could always just make a reservation at one of their restaurants to appreciate the view. I won't stay again next time I'm in HK.

Reviews.Title: “What a View !”
Reviews.Author: Brandon228
Reviews.Content: Tallest hotel on earth gives you a breathtaking view of HK island from Kowloon. Easy commute from the airport via express train . Around ICC, you have the Elements mall where you can find all the designer labels at duty free prices , Well its tax free shopping in HK ...Great place to people watch as well dressed diners & drinkers queue to get up to restaurants & bar @ The Ritz... Ask the concierge to direct your cabby to the nearest Tim Ho Wan for the best local Dim Sum/Yum Cha. Get there early as the queue starts forming right at opening hours.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing view, but disappointing interior/design”
Reviews.Author: o_poelmann
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Ritz early July and must say the location (on top of the highest building in HK) is amazing the views are fantastic all around (one does not need sea view rooms, as, because of its height, all rooms provide commanding views). We stayed on a club floor and room was great and the lounge was simply impeccable, simply no other way to describe the great service and decoration, BUT that was all the hotel had going for it, we where very disappointed about the restaurants, especially their restaurant 'Tosca', as the design was one that you would expect in a 3 star hotel in Asia, but not in such an expensive place as the Ritz. The food was OK, but also this was not up to standard. Their chocolate library: Even though we did manage to get a reservation, we decided later to give a miss as first of all, it had nothing to do with a library (no book in sight), it was an open area overlooking the ghastly Tosca restaurant (another reason for not dining at Tosca as people overlook you while dining). Most of all it was not the thing one would expect where one could enjoy a quiet high tea. In conclusion, the staff in the lounge was really fantastic and what one expects, but we do seriously wonder which parties approved the designs of the restaurants as clearly these are very wrong for a hotel that aspires to be one of the best in Asia, and we hope that the food quality will improve in Tosca (and please change the decoration)

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding restaurants...disappointing room”
Reviews.Author: ryu0803
Reviews.Content: Some reviews earlier mentioned that the location of this hotel is bad and I don't agree. The area, where the RC is located, is the future hotspot of Kowloon. A lot of construction is going on at this moment, and it is true that there isn't much within walking distance except the Elements Mall right now. In fact, the hotel is just minutes away by car from Nathan Road or Canton Road where the major activities are. Or, you can take the MTR, which is accessible through the lower level of the shopping mall, and travel one stop will take you to the IFC Mall in Central, Hong Kong island. So the location is not as remote as it seems, you just need to find out how to get around. Arriving in the hotel Rolls-Royce Phantom was a bliss. The moment we got inside our room, which was the Premier Island Suite, we were drawn immediately to the panoramic view of the Victoria Harbor. It was a cloudy day but what in front of our eyes was still the most spectacular view we have even seen of our city. We were very impressed. On the other hand, the room itself was a disappointment. Our room could be connected with the one next door and there is a very odd and useless space at the entrance. A short corridor leading to a long and narrow living room. Half of the living room is occupied by a large working desk. The remaining space is just too small for a sofa and they put a lounge chair in front of the TV instead. Watching TV lying sideway on the lounge chair was very uncomfortable. There is no walk-in closet. The floor to ceiling wardrobe with 2 big leaf doors inside the bedroom is a design failure. Every time we opened the door, the road to the bathroom was blocked. Fortunately, the bathroom is nice. However, at this room rate, we expected more comfort. We had access to the club lounge which is opened 24hrs. There is a dress code for the lounge which is smart casual, but no one cares to enforce it. We saw guest from Mainland China wearing pajamas like t-shirt with short and slipper from the room (yes, the white terry-cloth one with the RC logo) using the lounge. We don't understand why they bother with a dress code when the staff didn't even turn away guests in the hotel slipper. Be prepared to meet quite a number of those when you stay in this hotel. Dinner at Tosca was the highlight of our stay. From amuse-bouche to petit fours, every dish was prepared perfectly. Service was outstanding. We also had dim sum lunch as well as dinner at Tin Lung Heen. It is a good Chinese restaurant and some of what we ordered were quite delicious. Service was, again, wonderful. But if you only have time to try one, go for the Italian. We also went for drinks at Ozone after dinner and the place was fun and lively after dark. We visited the spa twice for facial and massage. This is the second Espa in Hong Kong and the first one is at the Peninsula Hotel. We go to the Espa at the Peninsula very often. Judging from the facilities as well as the treatment quality, we definitely recommend the Espa at the Peninsula over the one here. However, the spa suite for couple here is nicer than the one at the Peninsula Hotel. I rated this hotel average because the suite did not meet our expectation and the spa is far below the standard of a luxurious hotel. On the other hand, the RC staff are very professional and service level is high. In addition to that, there are two very good restaurants and an amazing view of Hong Kong. So I still recommend the Ritz Carlton Hong Kong, the highest hotel in world.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it and will be back!! :D”
Reviews.Author: betma12
Reviews.Content: Room: Spectacular View, looking at the Victoria Harbour ! It's clean, tidy and comfy. Food: Lounge - The staff offered us a nice sofa looking at the Hong Kong Island side and Victoria Harbour. The high tea was pretty standard, but it tasted delicious! Chocolate library - Service was a bit slow. We have waited this high tea for an hour+ after siting down. This high tea was different from the one at the Lounge. Most of the food contained chocolate ingredients! A bit heavy but would recommend if you love chocolate. Tin Lung Heen - We had a private room for 6 pax. (min HKD $8000 spending is required) The view was amazing, looking over New Territories. Most of the food was excellent except the steam fish. We didn't tried the abalone and shark fin, as we heard it wasn't that good. Tosca - Signature Tasting Menu was fine. Service was a bit slow... eating from 8pm to 11:15pm... almost fell asleep... zzz... Staff: Front Desk - Good Product knowledge + friendly. He offered us a late check out too. F&B outlet - Friendly and Fun Poolside - Helpful and friendly! Misc: Decor - The decoration is Okay. Looks a bit like the ones in Macau actually... Pool - Great Pool at 118/F with an interesting LED Screen, showing a beach image and sometimes an undersea image. Jacuzzi - at the top of the highest building in Hong Kong! Awesome! Location - next to a shopping mall named Element. Great Shopping Mall. We love this hotel and we will be back :D

Reviews.Title: “Love this Hotel - Great Experience”
Reviews.Author: Chicagojr29
Reviews.Content: Ritz-Carlton Hong Kong is an excellent Hotel. Staff is friendly, organized, and professional. House keeping top notch. Concierge was knowledgeable and made things easy. Rooms are clean, modern, with incredible views. Our room was on teh 112th floor. Great workout area, pool, and hottub on the 118th floor!! This hotel is an "experience" that everyone should do at least once. Incredible building, hotel and service. Stayed June 30-July 2nd 2011.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular in every respect”
Reviews.Author: MasterHarper
Reviews.Content: My suite on 107th floor was spectacular. Beautifully appointed with stunning views over HK harbor. The staff are so gracious and well trained that this is truly a special place. Even though it only opened in March it is a well-polished class act and will surely make its mark as one of the world's great hotels. And the Italian restaurant on floor 102 should not be missed.

Reviews.Title: “Sensory overload...”
Reviews.Author: SixStarQueen
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for one night to celebrate our 23rd anniversary. My husband made the reservation and had informed them ahead of time that it was an anniversary celebration. At the reception desk my husband was asked for his Hong Kong ID and I presented mine as well, the receptionist's response was, "Oh are you staying here too?" Ummm, why else was I standing there with an overnight bag?! Our room had a greeting card from the GM addressed only to my husband congratulating him on his wedding anniversary and thanking him for choosing the Ritz! The room was nice, the view was fabulous from the 113th floor. We had the full Hong Kong Central view as well as TST harbour. Amenities from Asprey Purple Water, comfortable bed, sufficient towels and very clean rooms.
