We did notice however our clothes were damp in the closet so perhaps the air conditioning isn't enough to act as a dehumidifier. The hotel is decorated to the hilt! It's an over the top, over done, over glitzed show piece. Someone was given free reign in a decorator's showroom and rather than make a few key choices they went crazy and cleared the floor and shelves of every design element! There's glass, chrome, marble, lazer cut metal, Swarovski crystals, Swarovski crytals, Swarovski crystals, water features, lit up flooring, glass curtains, sand blasted sculpted walls.... just too, too much. It's a hotel more fitting for Macau than Hong Kong. It's 70's decor reincarnated in a horrible way. The mainland Chinese love it though because they are EVERYWHERE! Service was good, the staff are friendly and helpful. We went up to Ozone for a pre- dinner drink, very young hip crowd again the view up there was beautiful and it was an experience. However sitting down at one of the sofas meant you have to spend a minimum of $15,000 HKD. We had dinner at Tosca. Fantastic food, fantastic service the only let down was the constant assault of flashes from cameras overhead due to the restaurants location. Tosca sits one floor below the check-in reception area which is open to the restaurant below. There is a constant flow of people overhead posing for photos and taking photos of the restaurant, this becomes very disconcerting as one is dining. At one point a group of 6 European tourists were lead into the dining room and they promptly stood around our table (we had a window side table) taking photographs of the harbour view as we were trying to enjoy our dinner!!! My husband saw them being lead in by the restaurant receptionist and had assumed they were there for dinner but they only wanted to take photos. I'm glad I experienced it but I would not chose to return to the Ritz. It's a mistake to design a hotel that fights against the beautiful harbour view rather than compliment it. If you want to see a new hotel done right in every way go to The Upper House in Pacific Place. Valet overnight parking cost $700 HKD.

Reviews.Title: “excellent service and unbelievable views!”
Reviews.Author: chiara76_27
Reviews.Content: I staied in Hong Kong on a business trip back in May. I was very curious to see The Ritz-Carlton as many people talked to me about it. I arrived in the evening on a cloudy day and when I checked in in my room the clouds were down below me! I never felt like this in any other hotel room, looking at clouds from above it is something I will always remember!On the next day with the clear sky I was able to see all of HK in front of me, you could stay there wathcing for hours! Club Lounge service was impeccable and extremely helpful, efficient and quick when asking for urgent business support on documents I had to send and receive; my only regret is that I could not have time to taste Tosca food or try the Spa but facilities looked fantastic and staff genuine and warm. I loved the restaurants concept and the great attention to each design details. The Hotel Manager guided me trough the ideas while having a coffee on the lounge with again a wonderful view right in front of HK. I wil come back for sure on leisure and reccomend it to all my friends! One of the best Ritz-Carlton properties I have visited for sure!

Reviews.Title: “Great place”
Reviews.Author: KimYu
Reviews.Content: A lot smiles. especially extra smiles and services in the GYM and swimming pool. And nice room, everything is SO new. house cleaner and front desk are also hospitality.

Reviews.Title: “Most spectacular service ever! And the property is just breathtaking!”
Reviews.Author: LorelaiUSA
Reviews.Content: Wowowow!!! We just left the hotel last night after a romantic weekend and I immediately made another reservation for the next weekend! I have never been in such a spectacular hospitality environment and so far this is the best Ritz Carlton we've ever stayed at (we have about 15 major trips per year in 4-5* hotels)! After reading all the reviews about this hotel I believe more than ever that some people love to be unhappy and complain about everything. Whatever, their loss. This hotel is an amazing demonstration of perfect service chain, from check-in to check-out and follow ups. We arrived by express train from the airport (most convenient) and it was a short walk to the Ritz. When I entered the hotel I was immediately surrounded by a sea of smiles and genuine welcome greetings! The concierge himself accompanied us to the front desk office on the 103rd floor and was extremely pleasant and informative. At the front desk, the very lovely and mostly efficient Dorothy gave us the room key, walked us to the elevator, all smiles and impeccable posture. Our room was spectacular! The most impressive interior design, state of the art bathroom, TV in the tub (a dream come true), technology for every single need, perfect coffee and tea maker, superb linen and the VIEW!!! OMG!!! WHAT A VIEW! We also received a delicious chocolate cake as a welcome gift from the GM since this was a special anniversary for us. Ten minutes later, while I was still in awe with the beauty of the room, we got a call from Miss Dorothy from front desk who took the liberty to send me some hot tea with lemon and water since she noticed that I'm fighting with a really laryngitis! How about that? We went in the evening to the Ozone club. Great venue, very classy, young crowd and good cocktails. And the service just as perfect as everywhere else. The club lounge is a MUST! Delicious food all day and again, the service! I teach service for a living and so far I have never seen such an impressive team! They also acknowledge that I don't have a voice due to my laryngitis and they started to fuss around me with hot water and lemon and advices! I have never been happier to be sick! Really! oh, and i should mention, late in the evening, I was sent up in the room again hot tea, lemon and honey and a special advice from the room service manager on how to take care of my health! The next day, we had a beautiful breakfast in the club level. I have noticed that the guests also seemed to be very happy and smiling. Everybody seemed to be very friendly and a lot of spontaneous conversations started among the guests. We met a few very nice people and one of the guests noticed that I cannot speak and she went to the chef and asked him to prepare me a special chinese porridge that works miracles! again, i felt like my laryngitis was a blessing in disguise! Everybody in the staff was constantly checking up on all the guests (without being too invasive). Everybody that we spoke with was very, very impressed with the hotel. For lunch I went by myself to the Lounge and I had a superb table by the window. Jason, my waiter was one of the most respectful and pleasant gentleman that I had the pleasure to meet. The food was amazing and I chose from the Asian menu whatever he recommended since I was not familiar with all the food items. Let me say, I had the best soy sauce in the world! The apple tart desert was divine! The pool and the gym are beyond imagination! It feels like you are somewhere on a different planet! I tried the pool, the steam bath and the hot tub outside and I almost cried when I had to leave :)) We made a reservation in the evening in the Chinese restaurant and since they knew we are celebrating, we received a special table by the window and a special menu designed for us!!!! We didn't even have to order anything! The champagne, offered by the management was ready for us when we arrived and minutes later, Mr.Cristiano Rinaldi, the hotel manager came to greet us in person. Useless to say, that was the best Chinese food we ever had and I will never be able to eat chinese food in USA without a sad face! If at this point you reader are still unimpressed, how about this? Later, when we returned to our spectacular room, I noticed a gift on the table. Jason, the waiter from the lounge sent me a complimentary bottle of the soy sauce that I liked so much! The check-out was just as pleasant! Miss Dorothy was there, asking about my health. Even the hotel manager, who just walked by came over to ask if I'm feeling better since he has heard that I was under the weather (it was really just a laryngitis!). Miss Tracey Oliver personally walked us out and waited for our car to arrive. When she waived good buy along with the concierge gentleman, I felt like I'm leaving family! So, enough to say that I am crazy about this place. The property is really amazing but would be just a cold, empty, superb place without the extraordinary staff of the Ritz Carlton! We were supposed to go to Singapore for the weekend and try the Raffles Hotel but honestly, last night I canceled the plans and I just emailed Miss Tracey asking her to make us a reservation for this following weekend! We still need to try the Tosca, the Italian restaurant and see the friendly faces of the ladies and gentlemen from the Ritz Carlton Hong Kong!

Reviews.Title: “really higher”
Reviews.Author: buttefly23
Reviews.Content: i stayed at this hotel for one night, as it is the highest hotel now and is just new openning. i booked one harbour view room,actually if u want to see the night view of the harbour, too difficult to see it , it must depend on the weather when u stay at almost 400m. so next time i will choose the city view room as the price will be lower. when i booked i saw some reviews complaining that it is not easy to find out the door of the hotel. when i arrived, i know why it comes as if no car straight arrived to the hotel hall door u will be tired to take the baggage through the CFC (shopping mall) and then take lift to the ninth floor then arrived at the hall. so if choose it ,must arrived by car!!! the room is fantastic, with large washroom i like it very much. and the bed is comfotable, i also like the carpet and the slipper, good matching when i was walking on the floor. but seems they did not good at the detail, as i m chinese so i dont know how use everykind coffee machine, the machine let me feel so dumb, no any introduction of it, so i had to call to ask how to use it. and when i went to the swimming pool , by the way it is the highest swimming pool, the changeroom also have this problem, no any introducion of the safety lock, first i thought maybe i m too dumb to use it , then asked again. when i was going to leave, i met another lady also didnt know how to use it . all service is good, worth to stay

Reviews.Title: “Stay Elsewhere”
Reviews.Author: iyorito
Reviews.Content: Warm greetings by doormen as I got off my friend’s BMW. However, as I entered the hotel, the hotel staffs gave me a long face, stopped me and did not allow me to go on to the lift lobby. The staffs told me that they must check on their iPad if I "really" held a room reservation. It was odd since I had a carry-on luggage with me so obviously I was checking-in to the hotel. 5-10 minutes wasted here. Once they confirmed that I "REALLY" had a reservation, they allowed me to go up to the 103rd floor main lobby. As I got off the lift, I was approached by a female staff, and she pointed me to go to the reception desk on the left hand side. Since I was booked on the club floor, I told her that I wanted to go up to the club lounge to check-in. The request was denied (or may be she did not understand English), and she forced me to go to the reception, Communist Chinese Beijing Friendship Store style if you get the picture. At the reception, the receptionist asked for my passport which I presented. After a few minutes, he goes "Oh, you have a reservation on the club floor, go up to the club lounge to check-in!!!!!". That staff at the lift lobby! Another 5-10 minutes wasted here. Finally, I was allowed to go up to the club lounge to check-in. The check-in process at the club lounge was uneventful since that lady who took care of me was very competent and had no problem communicating in English. However, it took standard 5-10 minutes here again, so at the end of the day, it took me half an hour to get to my assigned room from the entrance of the hotel. Why not just have the reception on the ground floor?! After 15.5 hours flight direct from New York, it was very unpleasant to go through this unnecessary experience. It was a loooooong way from the ground floor to the room. Anybody who plans to stay here MUST be prepared for it since it is really a pain. The decor of the hotel is very Dubai, Main Land China kitsch. I do not particularly fancy this "in your face" decor but one might appreciate it. The room I stayed in was small, definitely not 50 square metres as advertised. It felt much smaller. It had 40 square metres at best. The marble top of the sink in the bathroom was cracked in a very obvious area, poorly amended. They stayed cheap. The toilet was running the whole time but didn't bother me that much since I wore ear plugs to go to sleep. No ice bucket placed at turn down. Asprey bathroom amenties were nice. Nice couple of chocholates placed at turndown. The food presentation during the cocktail hour was shamefully shabby. There was very little choice. There were some cheeses but no bread or crackers. Some strange tartare of something with salmon roe on it and hot and sour soup! Very down to earth western Chinese takeaway choice!!! Breakfast presentation was decent. Coffee was do it yourself Nespresso, kind of a cheap machine for a Ritz-Carlton Club lounge to be honest. It made a decent cup of espresso nonetheless. I wrote all of above on a comment card but nobody replied to me. I wrote 2 emails to the Guest Recognition Manager, but I was not recognised and ignored. I sorted to email the General Manager, but again, casually ignored until I sorted to contact the headquarters in the US. Like the other traveller mentioned, the GM is not a great responder. And it seems that it is the case top down. Don't get me wrong, though, 60% of the staffs I dealt with seemed genuinely trying to make you happy. The location of the hotel is remote, and you cannot walk to anywhere except to the Element Mall downstairs. If you plan to have a chauffeur driven car all the time, the location is a none issue, but for someone who need to go outside of ICC/Elements complex, it is unbelievably inconvenient. I suppose there is an Airport Express or Tung Chung line that goes to Central but I did not try since I was extremely tired and lazy. Bottom line: Unless you are to sightsee the "highest hotel in the world", staying one night only, it is BEST TO AVOID this new Ritz-Carlton, Hong Kong and stick to the Peninsula, the Mandarin Oriental (old and new) or the Four Seasons as it is seriously inconvenient (unless you are doing business with Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley or Credit Suisse whose offices are in the building) and the service is mediocre at best. It is also a HUGE hassle to get to the room from the ground floor taking two different lifts changing on the 103rd floor. Half of the building is facing the wrong side and has an ugly view. The rooms are much smaller than advertised. Scam.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic location”
Reviews.Author: maisoncote
Reviews.Content: First I have to say we have Dim sum and Dinner at the Chinese Restaurant on the 102 floor of the new Ritz Carlton ICC building Hong kong I could not say enough good things about the facility, arriving on the main floor we are welcome and ask where we are going, we have reservation to Tin Lung Heen for Dim sum ! the security was pretty impressive we get on our way to the Ritz Carlton hotel lobby on the 103 floor, then down couple step to the Restaurant on the 102 floor, we saw from the corner of our eye a Chocolate Library so we save some space for Chocolate high tea, the place is new & I was empress and very happy to have the chance to experiment this Canton Cuisine with a 5 Star flair The abalone tart, the pork bun made from Iberia pork where so delicious I still crave them now then I am back to Vancouver (I post some pick on my blog at maisoncote.com), well we love our Dim sum so much, we request a reservation for a evening before coming back home, we where lucky to have a reservation as we understand they are fully book till August. The Dinner did not disappoint it was fantastic, the service outstanding, even the tea was wonderful we finish with a night cap at Ozone on the 118 floor a bit to young and hip for me but I did enjoy the great view I did not stay at this hotel but I was reacting to the other gentlemen with a very bad experience, I was welcome in English everywhere in HK and Macau (I am white but I am French Canadian and they do there best to welcome you, I do understand the Hong Kong Sensibility to be welcome in Cantonese, as there is so many tourist from Mainland China, Just go on Canton road at Chanel or Louis Vuitton and you see 100's of Mainland Chinese waiting in line to buy Luxury good from noon to 11 PM, I guest they are the main force bringing money to HK so I guest it is acceptable to be Welcome in Mandarin. Hong kong is my prefect city in the whole world & I am always empress by the force of great people working together to make a wonderful world top City

Reviews.Title: “A room with a view like no other.”
Reviews.Author: jhbboy
Reviews.Content: I recently travelled to Hong Kong with the specific intent to stay at the Ritz Carlton Hong Kong. I have been watching the tower go up, during my many visits to the region over the past five years, so I decided that I would make it a point of staying there as soon as possible, booking my room the day they opened the website to reservations. Upon arrival on the 22nd April the hotel was a little over three weeks old, but in fairness to the team all was well and besides dirty windows, none of the normal opening blues I expected was experienced. I was met at the airport by three members of staff who were waiting for me at the Customs exit into the arrival hall, my baggage was immediately taken from me and I was led to the hotel car area, a minutes walk away. Waiting for me was the hotels Silver Rolls Royce Phantom registration number PJ 1113. The driver introduced himself, and upon driving off asked if I was in a hurry to get to the hotel, or if I preferred the scenic 'taking it easy' route, I chose the latter relaxed option. He also apologised for the incorrect pronunciation of my name – I have one of those horrible last names, and quickly called the hotel to say he had Mr xxxx safely onboard. The drivers English was excellent and his ability to converse on topics relevant to my country in an informed manner was impressive. The drive was over all to soon and we had arrived on level 9 at the ICC tower. The door was opened for me by Kit from the club lounge, who welcomed me to the hotel and further introduced me to the manager on duty who was also waiting for me. I wanted to take some arrival pictures, he immediately offered to do the honors, reassuring me he was camera friendly, correctly identifying my camera model and subtly letting me know he had a model one up on that. Photo's done I was escorted into the lobby and all the doormen and the elevator police greeted me by name pronounced correctly – no doubt thanks to the drivers earlier call. We travelled 52 seconds up to level 103 where he pointed out the check in area, concierge, restaurants and the led me to the guest lifts and we immediately went up to floor 115 where I was given the option to choose between room 115-19 facing to the South East or 115-25 facing South West, I ended settling on 115-19. Check in was effectively a case of giving me the key cards to my room (proximity type not magnetic stripe), asking for one signature and to see my passport, it cannot get any easier than that. In your room at your own desk without queues or forms I cannot see an easier option. Facilities in the room and hotel were clearly explained and for breakfast I was offered 3 options, option 1 in the Lounge and Bar on floor 102, option 2 in the club lounge or, Option 3 BOTH! The room itself is fairly ordinary, king bed, work desk, comfy lounge chair, large screen LED HD television, blu ray player, large cupboards and a bathroom with double vanity, separate shower, and deep bath with television. The difference is in the quality, having slept in far too many hotel beds I can safely say that this hotel has the most comfortable bed I have ever slept in. The internet connectivity (complimentary of course) is incredibly fast. And then of course the pièce de résistance is the view, simply unbeatable, even when compared to the view at the peak. The view itself is reason enough to stay at the hotel, I ended up staying in a harbour view room, but could safely recommend a view to any direction, they are all amazing! For some reason I preferred the view slightly lower down on 102, compared to that of my room on 115 or at the pool at 118. Personal choice I guess, but no need to demand a high up room. The Ritz Carlton club lounge on 116 has amazing views with snacks and drinks on offer 24/7. The lounge also features complimentary usage of their computers, concierge and express checkout. Meals are as follows: Breakfast 06h30 – 10h30, light snacks 11h30 – 14h00, high tea 15h00 – 17h00, hors d'oeuvres 17h30 – 19h30, desserts 20h30 – 22h30 and late night snacks 23h00 – 06h00. Great service was received from Phoebe and Kit in the lounge at all times, again always addressed by name, with just enough interaction to be friendly yet not intrusive. Special mention has to be made of Mr Herve Yen the manager at the lounge, unlike most managers he is hands on, and not above rudimentary jobs like clearing tables, yet he is always willing to chat, assist and is genuinely welcoming and friendly. He even specially ordered to the lounge a meal not on the menu without blinking an eye. The quality of all foods was of an extremely high standard. My only concern is that the additional cost for lounge access is simply not justifiable, the lounges at other hotels have far more on offer. Simple things like a wider selection for non drinkers, and more plain snacks, even as basic as crisps comes to mind. Breakfast at the Lounge and Bar was incredible, the selection both Western and Asian vast, matched with friendly, prompt and professional service. The view at breakfast was by far the biggest highlight, you sit on a bench side by side and look out over the harbour to Hong Kong island, incredible! On one morning I took my camera to breakfast and as was each morning met by Winky, who of her own offered to take me around the entire 102 floor for photo's after breakfast. A small detail that really makes you feel welcome. I also ate at Tin Lung Heen the chinese restaurant. Food and service was good, although pricey and in a city like Hong Kong difficult to recommend with so many other great and in my opinion much better options. Next time I will try Tosca. The swimming pool on the roof deserves special mention, a regular pool is located indoors with a digital LED roof and wall, simulating blue skies and whisper clouds for the perfect tropical island atmosphere irrespective of the weather outside. A hot pool and a near freezing plunge pool are also on offer, the later impossible to enjoy for more than a few minutes unless your name is Vladimir, Yuri or Alexi. The hot tub outside is awesome. Changing rooms, with sauna, showers, bottled water, large towels and slippers are provided. One small complaint here is that the slippers are not suitable for western feet, and are probably a size 7 or 8, they should have some size 10 or even 11 available. The gym is also on level 118, ample modern equipment is available with the cardio equipment having TV, Internet, Facebook, and twitter access. At all times I was recognised and greeted by name on level 9, 103 and in the lounge, despite shift changes, a feat worth mentioning. Further a colleague who joined me; a South African born Chinese was always greeted in English, something he appreciated as he is usually addressed in Cantonese in Hong Kong. Overall the experience at the hotel was very good, but unfortunately not without flaws. Sadly for a hotel which has pitched itself at such a high level, in both price and hype I have to be more critical than what I would be of other hotels in Hong Kong. For first time visitors the location at Kowloon station is far from convenient, with the exception journeys to central station, Disney or the outlet shopping, and big Buddha at Tung Chung. Journeys to TST, Jordan, YMT and Mongkok require the use of a taxi, and destinations along the island line other than central require a longish walk between the lines. The station at Kowloon although in the basement is also a fair walk requiring travel on two elevators and seven escalators. Unless you have carry on luggage I would not advocate using the Airport express either as you are on your own to the hotel lobby. For late flights home, like mine at midnight, I do however recommended checking in at Kowloon station, you can simply drop off your luggage, get your boarding card and spend the rest of the day enjoying the city heading to the airport at only 9:30pm. A major gripe however is day visitors visiting the hotel, this is the source of untold annoyance as they clog up the lobby, and crowd the elevators. I would recommended the hotel starts a queue on level 8 at the entrance to the hotel from elements and reserves one elevator for them, the other three can be used exclusively by actual guests. Currently the elevator police only call the elevator once a sufficient group have gathered, this happens on level 9 and 103. As a guest I do not want to wait, I also got the impression at times that not all elevators where in service. Personally I believe non guests should go to the observatory in the building, if they want to enjoy the view, and not pretend to be interested in a drink at the bar. I had wanted to bring this up with Mark DeCocinis as he invited contact in my welcome letter, but didn't want to be petty. However after trying to make reservations for Tin Lung Heen unsuccessfully as they were sold out, I decided to raise my concerns with him. Besides the elevator issue I believe that a table should always be available to hotel guests and not sold out in advance to visitors staying elsewhere. After complaining in the Club Lounge a “last table” was found, to add insult to injury though the restaurant never exceeded 50% capacity in the three hours we dined there. Very Weird. Sadly despite me asking two people in the Club Lounge on three separate occasions – I trust that at least one of them gave my message to him, he never had the decency to find the time in the three days thereafter to contact me to discuss my concerns. Hotel management who believe they are bigger than their title have a lot to learn and it is truly disappointing that the manger of a hotel like the Ritz Carlton receives my biggest criticism. Shame on you Mark, especially in lieu of the genuine effort your staff are putting in to making this a great hotel. Despite this I would recommend staying at the Ritz Carlton, especially for guests looking for good service on special occasions in a truly spectacular location (height of building not area of building). The people and the service are what make this place special, in fairness had the room rate been HK$3500 or less the hotel would be perfect and my best in world. However I would not recommend the hotel for first time visitors looking for a central location wanting to explore the city.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing Experience at the Spa”
Reviews.Author: Bluelagoon771
Reviews.Content: The newly established Ritz Carlton in Kowloon is located right next to the Kowloon station. There are restaurants if you go down all the way to Elements next door, but otherwise the hotel restaurants are fully booked all the way till end of June, and impossible to dine in their nice Cantonese or Italian restaurants. There are numerous spectators visiting the bar Ozone, and it's just not a great atmosphere at the moment. Most disappointingly, the spa.. all the therapists speaks good English which was impressive but overall the treatment was very basic. The experience and technique of the therapists were below average and my sore back felt even more sore after the therapy. I paid over 400 USD for a 100minute massage, and the therapy was very disappointing. At the same time, there seems to be no 'relaxation room' post therapy_ where many spas in Hong Kong and Kowloon such as Mandarin Oriental, Langham Hotel, Intercontinental, W Hotel, and Peninsula has. It's nice to be able to enjoy the sauna, jacuzzi, and relaxation room with a bit of tea after the treatment... Overall the experience was very disappointing.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular!”
Reviews.Author: AZJetSet
Reviews.Content: My husband and I are no strangers to the luxury hotel market having stayed at some of the world's most iconic, luxury properties including the Four Seasons Firenze, Four Seasons Budapest, Park Hyatt Paris, Four Seasons Buenos Aires etc... Combine the greatness from all of our favorites and we still don't come close to the level of service that we experienced at the Ritz Carlton Hong Kong. What's more, the hotel had only been open for a week upon our arrival! We were celebrating our 14th Wedding Anniversary and received a complimentary upgrade to a Harbor View Room. I don't think from 109 floors up it is possible to have a bad view, but the harbor view was incredible - especially during the evening light show. The room was very large by city standards and everything was gleaming. The bathroom was gorgeous, decked in beautiful marble. It was spa-like with an enormous rain shower-head and separate, large soaking tub. We especially enjoyed the relaxing bath salts. However, we were a little let down by the bath products which seemed a bit generic (Whatever happened to the Bulgari products or some sort of signature scented soap? I know the hotel has wonderful signature scent flowing throughout the lobby - it would make for a nice bath amenity). We paid for an upgrade to the Club Level which gave us access to a magnificent lounge staffed by the most professional and personable concierges imaginable. We were consistently amazed by Kit and Judy. Nothing was too much to ask and honestly, they anticipated our needs before we knew what we wanted. From recommendations for restaurants and shopping to always remembering our drink preferences. We were astounded by their genuine hospitality every time we visited. We also have to mention Phoebe and Elisa who were also exceptional. I should also mention that the Club Level offers 24-7 food and beverages. There was a full breakfast offered each morning (eggs cooked to order) and other traditional offerings. Additionally, the lounge serves lunch, afternoon tea, evening hors d'oeuvres, desserts and late night snacks. Did I mention that the lounge is on the 116th floor with incredible views? We made good use of the swimming pool located on the 118th Floor as well as the jacuzzi. The views from the pool were extraordinary - but if you're not easily impressed there is always the LCD images above the pool to captivate you. The location of the hotel is also magnificent. It is located within the new ICC Tower which, at 118 Floors, is the tallest building in Hong Kong. The building sits atop of the Elements shopping mall which is filled with luxury shops and restaurants. More importantly, Kowloon Station is located at the mall with access to the Airport Express Train. We were able to check in for our flight right at the station - no baggage to haul on the train - we checked the bags and they arrived at our destination - couldn't have been easier! Hats off to the bellman who carted our luggage all the way down to the station for us! I cannot imagine that he was expected to do that - but he did so enthusiastically! Finally, every staff member went out of there way to make us feel welcome. From the simplest gesture of saying hello to offering to take our photos or remembering our preferences in the hotel restaurant. We couldn't have been happier with our stay and highly recommend. Bar none THE -BEST-HOTEL-IN-THE-WORLD!!

Reviews.Title: “If you like hotels in Office Towers - This is a place for you”
Reviews.Author: MikeyR
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the new Ritz Carlton Hong Kong last week with colleagues on a business trip to HK. Part of the reason we stayed there was to try the new “tallest hotel in the world” place, and let’s be honest, as big as Hong Kong is, there are not a whole lot of choices. Let me start by saying that I’m not a fan of hotels that are sandwiched inside tall office towers, I like a hotel where the lobby is on the first floor, and where you feel that you are in a hotel at all times. This hotel is in the HK’s tallest building, at 118 floors, the hotel lobby is on the 103 floor, with guest rooms all the way up to the 118 (where the lounge is). You can enter the hotel from the 9th floor lobby, which isn’t easy to find by car or taxi, or from inside the Elements mall, a few escalators, a lift or two, and you are on the 9th floor, then a turbo jet lift to the 103rd floor to check in. There’s a miniscule lobby like space on the 9th floor, and virtually no lobby on the 103rd floor. The views as expected are amazing, but surprisingly the noise even at 110th floor where my room was, is still loud. The hotel has only been open for a few weeks, and the teething problems are there, but that’s to be expected. As another reviewer said, there’s either too many staff milling about, or none. But the congregation of staff at the lifts got on my nerves very quickly. Not sure why they need 3 or even more people directing traffic. The Ozone bar on the 118th floor seems to be a great draw, and the lines in the 9th floor lobby are very long, the bar itself is quite ordinary, and the sushi bar menu was very mediocre. And getting asked to show your room key every time you go in and out of the hotel by the security staff was a pain, and also annoying, I understand that they are trying to control the traffic in and out of the hotel, especially to the 118th floor, but I’m sure there are better ways than what they are currently doing. The rooms are very standard, oddly shaped, in a long narrow corridor like design for a waiting/sitting area to separate it from the bedroom. The baths are out of this world, so are the beds (of course they are also very new). The lounge on the 116th is one of the best, well stocked, and great staff. Our biggest complaint in this hotel were the lifts, the card reader didn’t work most of the times, and I had to have the keys exchanged multiple times daily. Not sure what the deal was, it was a running joke with other guests, on whose key might work. For the value, I would stay at the Peninsula or Mandarin (even though a bit older), there you feel like you are in a hotel, and all the kinks have been ironed out. Not a place I would go back to anytime soon.

Reviews.Title: “Good but needs a lot of work”
Reviews.Author: EllisdadLondon
Reviews.Content: As a brand new hotel the RC HK is still finding its feet. On the plus side it has a great location, fantastic views and excellent facilities (the swimming pool, gym etc are second to none). However there clearly are staffing issues. On check in I was told i had been upgraded only to find i was given the room i had booked. There was a noise coming from the window so I had to wait an hour whilst two workmen came to try and fix it. Eventually i was given another room, at the same standard. Generally there either appear to be too many or too few staff depending on your needs. Coming out of the elevator at lobby level there were times when there would be up to six staff waiting to push you in the direction they wanted you to go in. It was hard to explore the hotel on your own without staff coming up to you and asking what you were doing. Several times the phone would go unanswered when calling 'service experience'. There is often an impersonal and generic feel the the experience. In the course of a four night stay I never saw the same staff twice and nobody ever knew my name. This meant that every time I entered the lobby I was challenged by a member of staff when I went to use the lift. I understand that for security they need to be aware of visitors but it became tiresome having to explain that I was a guest every time I entered. Breakfast finishes at 10.30 each day. Usually that means you have some leeway after to linger but not here - the cleaners start hoovering around the tables at 10.30 precisely. The bedrooms are very comfortable - faultless beds and bathrooms. But again there is a generic feel, and no indication that you are even in Asia let along Hong Kong. And soundproofing is a big issue - i could hear everything from the next door bedroom - voices, phones - everything. I would suggest that for a couple of nights on business this hotel would be fine, for leisure I would not recommend it. I was due to stay for a week but moved to the Upper House after four nights where I had a much more positive experience.

Reviews.Title: “Nice view of Symphony of Lights”
Reviews.Author: jarusoba
Reviews.Content: Nice hotel. Great views. Great service. Great spa. Great pool. The only criticism is the windows in our suite were not clean enough.

Reviews.Title: “SUPERB”
Reviews.Author: gokhanHk
Reviews.Content: Superb service , nice Italian food, Warm Hospitality , Nice location. . Worths the money you pay The rooms are just OK , nothing surprising.

Reviews.Title: “Welcome back in my personal list of best Hotels in the world”
Reviews.Author: nyx999
Reviews.Content: The old Ritz Carlton in Central closed down 3 years ago and the building was demolished. I was very fortunate to enjoy the very first days of the NEW Ritz Carlton with my family. And what a place they picked to open their doors again. They relocated to a truly spectacular spot in Hong Kong; on the top floors of the new ICC building at Kowloon side. It is officially the highest Hotel in the word. Upon arrival we were welcomed in a stylish, luxurious lobby. If desired, we could have even gotten a nice cup of tea. We were guided to the elevators and 'lifted' by means of a single elevator-trip of 52 seconds to the 103rd floor. The lobby on the 103rd. floor is spacious and very nice. Check-in is on this floor. There are several restaurants. The famous Italian restaurant located in the old Ritz Carlton is re-situated next to the lobby. There is an open kitchen so one can see all the action. The food was (again) very pleasant. Besides this Italian restaurant Tosca, there is the Chinese restaurant Tin Lung Heen and a dining area specialised in dishes made off and with chocolate; The Chocolate Library. In the Lounge & Bar area an international menu is served all day long as well as breakfast. I loved the huge MEGA lamps! What a design. Materials used throughout the Hotel; lots of marble, leather and plush fabrics. Pleasant, relaxing, stylish and 'luxurious' colour schemes. The overall interior design & lighting is breathtaking. Very well done. The Ozone Rooftop Bar at the top floor is just spectacular when it’s dark; Incredible decoration. It will be one of THE places to be in Hong Kong. Rooms: Well appointed and spacious. Bathroom (with TV) in cream coloured marble, flat screen TV (wall mounted) etc.etc. Colour scheme used: brownish, leather wall fabrics. The swimming pool on the 118th floor is just stunning; the view is superb but also the clever use of flat screen panels next to and above the whole pool is fabulous; blue skies, moving white clouds and the likes. Very well designed. It’s the highest swimming pool in the world. But the best part of the Old Ritz has been moved to the NEW Ritz; the people and their genuine warmth and level of service. I always loved to stay in the Old Ritz Carlton and I was pleased to hear that a lot of the former employees have returned to the new Hotel. I will be a fan of this new place just as I was of the old one. Of course there were some small hiccups these first days but I am truly impressed. The Ozone Bar is from now on my most favourite spot in the world. And my kids felt themselves very welcomed as well. Thank you and congratulations with this new place. Just one question remains: will they place again this giant bouquet of Lilies back in the lobby…..? I always LOVED the smell of it; it was iconic.
